file_name: Kuutti 等 - 2021 - A Survey of Deep Learning Applications to Autonomous Vehicle Control.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 深度学习在自动驾驶车辆控制中的应用综述
structured_info.title_en: A Survey of Deep Learning Applications to Autonomous Vehicle Control
structured_info.abstract: Designing a controller for autonomous vehicles capable of providing adequate performance in all driving scenarios is challenging due to the highly complex environment and inability to test the system in the wide variety of scenarios which it may encounter after deployment. However, deep learning methods have shown great promise in not only providing excellent performance for complex and non-linear control problems, but also in generalising previously learned rules to new scenarios. For these reasons, the use of deep learning for vehicle control is becoming increasingly popular. Although important advancements have been achieved in this field, these works have not been fully summarised. This paper surveys a wide range of research works reported in the literature which aim to control a vehicle through deep learning methods. Although there exists overlap between control and perception, the focus of this paper is on vehicle control, rather than the wider perception problem which includes tasks such as semantic segmentation and object detection. The paper identifies the strengths and limitations of available deep learning methods through comparative analysis and discusses the research challenges in terms of computation, architecture selection, goal specification, generalisation, verification and validation, as well as safety. Overall, this survey brings timely and topical information to a rapidly evolving field relevant to intelligent transportation systems.
structured_info.methodology: Literature survey and comparative analysis of deep learning techniques (supervised learning, reinforcement learning, inverse reinforcement learning) applied to lateral, longitudinal, and simultaneous vehicle control. Includes categorization of approaches, performance evaluation, and challenge identification.
structured_info.conclusion: Deep learning shows promise for autonomous vehicle control but faces significant challenges including computational demands, architecture selection difficulties, reward function design for reinforcement learning, generalization to diverse environments, verification/validation complexities, and safety assurance. Future research should address these limitations and advance full vehicle control capabilities.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: Comprehensive survey of deep learning methods applied to autonomous vehicle control, categorizing approaches into lateral (steering), longitudinal (acceleration/braking), and simultaneous control. Highlights strengths, limitations, and research challenges.
Background_and_Motivation: Traffic accidents cause significant fatalities globally (e.g., 37,000 in US, 25,500 in EU annually), with human error responsible for 90% of accidents. Autonomous vehicles offer solutions for safety, congestion, pollution, and efficiency.

Motivation stems from limitations of rule-based controllers (difficulty in generalization, parameter tuning) and analytical solutions (poor handling of non-linearity). Deep learning promises adaptive, self-optimizing control through data.
Authors argue for urgency by linking autonomous vehicles to critical societal challenges: reducing accidents, improving fuel economy, enhancing traffic flow, and enabling car-sharing.

Specific control problem is framed within broader challenges of safe navigation in dynamic environments. Significance is established through statistics on accident causation and projected benefits of autonomy.
Contributes to intelligent transportation systems, machine learning, control theory, and computer vision through interdisciplinary integration.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: 1) Lateral control (steering via visual inputs), 2) Longitudinal control (acceleration/braking via sensor data), 3) Simultaneous control (integrated steering and acceleration).
Lateral and longitudinal control are logically distinct but must be combined for full autonomy. Deep learning bridges perception and action in end-to-end systems.

Key assumptions: Deep learning can overcome rule-based controller limitations; real-world driving complexity requires data-driven adaptability; simulation can effectively supplement real-world testing.
Contributes a systematic taxonomy and comparative analysis of methods, identifying gaps and synthesizing research challenges to guide future work.
Methodology: Survey methodology involves categorizing literature into lateral, longitudinal, and simultaneous control; comparing techniques (supervised, reinforcement, inverse reinforcement learning); and evaluating public datasets (KITTI, Waymo) and tools (NVIDIA Drive PX2).
Novelty lies in comprehensive synthesis of fragmented works. Applicability is evidenced by real-world/simulated case studies. Rationality stems from addressing gaps in existing summaries.

Data sources: Public datasets (KITTI, ApolloScape) and simulation tools (CARLA, TORCS). Representativeness is limited by environmental homogeneity in datasets; preprocessing includes augmentation and noise injection.
No experimental design; analysis rigor comes from comparative tables and challenge identification. Evaluation metrics include lane-keeping accuracy, collision rates, and computational efficiency.
Follows empirical machine learning paradigm, emphasizing data-driven optimization over model-based control, affecting perspective on adaptability vs. verifiability.
Results: Key results: Supervised learning excels in lateral control; reinforcement learning suits longitudinal control; simultaneous control remains challenging. Techniques show promise but exhibit noise, oscillation, and limited generalization.

Results are significant for demonstrating feasibility but reliability varies (e.g., collision mitigation works at TTC>1.5s but fails at 0.9s). Stability concerns arise from noisy outputs and simulation-to-reality gaps.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structure: Introduction → Deep learning review → Control applications (lateral, longitudinal, simultaneous) → Challenges → Conclusions.
Key steps: 1) Establish problem significance, 2) Introduce deep learning methods, 3) Categorize/appraise control approaches, 4) Synthesize challenges, 5) Recommend future directions.
Strengths: Clear categorization and challenge synthesis. Weaknesses: Limited critique of individual studies. Rebuttals: Acknowledges simulation limitations but defends its necessity for scalability.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: First comprehensive survey in this niche; timely synthesis of rapid advancements; clear challenge framework.
Methodology limitations: Heavy reliance on simulation; generalization barriers due to environmental complexity; safety verification difficulties.
Theoretical constraints: Data-driven paradigm limits interpretability and formal safety guarantees, restricting deployability in safety-critical contexts.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions itself as foundational synthesis in an emerging field, bridging machine learning and transportation research.
Uses technical terminology from both domains; authoritative tone through extensive citations (e.g., Pomerleau, NVIDIA); rhetorical emphasis on urgency via accident statistics.
Builds authority by citing seminal works (e.g., ALVINN, DAVE) and industry players (Waymo, NVIDIA). Motivations include filling literature gaps and accelerating safe deployment.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Conclusions: Deep learning enables adaptive vehicle control but faces computation, generalization, and safety challenges. Lateral/longitudinal control show promise; simultaneous control lags.

Future research: Address safety via interpretability and formal methods; improve full-vehicle control; handle complex scenarios (intersections, overtaking); enhance simulation-to-reality transfer; develop specialized architectures.
